Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Situation2: They see a swimmer struggling near the middle of the pool and need to stay vigilant to respond quickly.
Story: I had been looking forward to this family gathering for weeks. My daughter had organized everything, and my grandkids were buzzing with excitement to spend the afternoon with me. As a grandparent, I felt the weight of their expectations—stories to tell, games to play, memories to make. But as I stood at the edge of the pool, whistle around my neck, my other role pressed in. The pool was busy, and my eyes scanned the water, counting heads, watching for any sign of trouble. Suddenly, I noticed a swimmer flailing near the middle, their strokes growing frantic. My heart pounded. I knew I needed to stay focused, ready to jump in at a moment’s notice. Yet, behind me, I heard my granddaughter’s voice, calling for me to join the family for a group photo. I felt torn, the pull of family warmth on one side and the urgent responsibility of safety on the other. My mind raced, caught between the laughter of my loved ones and the silent plea of the struggling swimmer.
